Pyc - Python Command-Line Compiler

 

 

Prerequisites

The prerequisites to successfully run this application are:

  • Microsoft .NET Framework Version 3.5
    • Required to run IronPython on Windows Vista
    • Microsoft .NET Framework Version 2.0 SP1 or higher needed for Windows operating systems released prior to Windows Vista
    • Download from here
  • IronPython 2.0 distribution
    • If you are new to IronPython, please go over the tutorial that comes with this distribution
    • Download from here


Getting Started

From a command prompt, please navigate to the Pyc sample directory and copy the IronPython and DLR DLLs here.  With a typical MSI-based IronPython installation, this can be achieved by running commands similar to the following:

> pushd %WhereYouUnzippedTheSample%\Pyc

> copy "%ProgramFiles%\IronPython 2.0"\*.dll .

 

The compiled executables require the presence of IronPython.dll, Microsoft.Scripting.dll, etc. in the current directory.  If not found by the .NET runtime, the compiled executables will fail with "Unhandled Exception: System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'IronPython, ...".

Please make sure the folder structure in the Pyc directory is:

.\console_hw.py

.\IronPython.dll

.\IronPython.Modules.dll
.\Microsoft.Scripting.Core.dll
.\Microsoft.Scripting.dll
.\Microsoft.Scripting.ExtensionAttribute.dll

.\other_hw.py

.\pyc.py

.\readme.htm

.\winforms_hw.py

Overview

This sample demonstrates the use of the Python Hosting APIs to compile Python files into .NET executables.  The behavior of the generated files is actually quite similar to that of CPython files with the ".pyc" file extension.

For the list of command-line options, run:

    ipy.exe pyc.py


Command-Line Options

The format of the command-line for running pyc.py is as follows:

    ipy.exe pyc.py [options] file [file ...]

 

The available options are:

  • /? or /h
    Command-line help

  • /out:output_file
    The name of the output file. If omitted, the name of the last input file specified (with extension dll or exe) will be used for the output file.

  • /main:main_file.py
    The main module of the executable. This is the module whose code will be executed first in the compiled executable. If /out is omitted, the name of the output assembly will be: main_file.<extenstion>

  • /target:(exe|winexe)
    The target assembly type is an optional parameter. Console executable (exe) or windows executable (winexe).  Please note that regardless of which assembly type is passed to this flag, a 'dll' assembly will also be created.

  • /platform:(x86|x64)
    Optional argument to specify/restrict the target platform of the .NET assembly. Specifying x86 will set assembly requirement to 32-bit execution only. Default setting is to produce a platform independent .NET assembly.

Examples

  • ipy.exe pyc.py /main:console_hw.py
    Compiles console_hw.py into console executable console_hw.exe.

  • ipy.exe pyc.py other_hw.py /main:console_hw.py
    Compiles two input files (other_hw.py and console_hw.py) into console_hw.exe. Contents of console_hw.py will be executed directly.

  • ipy.exe pyc.py /main:winforms_hw.py /target:winexe
    Compiles winforms_hw.py into winforms_hw.exe and winforms_hw.dll.
